author: P.K. Stephan
content:
Hey guys! I am new to the community and happy to have finally taken the jump into the discord after being an avid listener since the beginning.

Just finished building my studio about half a year ago. I run a hybrid setup where everything is always connected and ready to go. All recording paths are accessed via an XLR patch-bay. Mixbus/Mastering gear is controlled by a Dangerous Liaison. Conversion is done via MADI and AES/EBU. Headphone CUE’s are analog and via AVB. I like having everything connected and mic’ed up because I notice that I only use the stuff that I can access quickly while producing/mixing. I went through a lot of trial and error building and working in this studio (been in this location for 1.5 years) so if anyone needs any input I would be happy to help!

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I tried to be the cool kid for so long, acting like I belonged when I felt like I didn’t, feigning nonchalance. Ultimately (likely too late in life,) I realized the people I was drawn to were the people who were unselfconsciously joyful. People who took real pleasure in the moment- not manic excitement, just unbridled joy. *That* shit is contagious.

author: chrissorem
content: @JakeTB  @jonmatteson @David Fuller  alright so I have to say I really like the PMC’6s and if I could I would trade my two-two 6’s. They feel more full range overall.  That being said I’m keeping my two two 6’s and the Neumann 420’s are filling the role that I’m looking for, which is a full range cabinet.  The 420’s frequency spectrum feels very top to bottom and very open.  The low end detail is very zoomed in. I definitely can hear more detail. The mid range also feels very detailed and the top end is nice and open but they are as bright as the PMC’s but I don’t feel like I’m missing any information.  After listening to various songs on the 420’s I thought damn these sound nice, and at the same time I thought but is that good? Like how will they respond actually working on them. Will they help my mixes or will they just sound good? So far they have been revealing and translating quite well. I was concerned about the 300-500hz. Feeling a little tucked in when listening to  finished mixes but as I put them to work I felt like they did show that info as well.  I really dig them and will likely buy them. But I think they might be a bit big for a single set of speakers and will still want to work on some  near fields. They definitely show me different things.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Okay here we go…

@ALXCPH found a couple on my camera roll. Excuse quality, one is when I showed my parents the studio for first time. Couple (long) notes…I’m sure @Nomograph Mastering can expand if he chooses:

Unf*ck designed the room. Ruairi you are incredible at this and I’m very grateful. The subtleties in the trade offs when designing a room are something I urge everyone to consider deeply as I learned when working with them!

1. Studio is built in my basement…13 feet long x 30 wide x 8 tall (including treatment). Back wall divides it length wise and makes the studio part 12x15 approx.

2. All treatment is built in…entire ceiling is stuffed with 9 inch pink fluffy, couple inch rockwool in the walls, tuned mass loaded vinyl behind the “housings” to L and R of listening position. Back wall is 6 inches of safe n sound in a frame built of 2x8s (by contractor) with a 24” door. It’s standing by friction just slid tight to ceiling. Quite precise measuring required to do that and make it sturdy so a door can open well

3. Since I get asked a lot…the wall finishes are acoustic felt board. Went that direction because install was way better than a fabric wall (they are firm and can be cut with an exacto knife). Also they are absorptive with no reflections…caveats apply if that’s good for a given space though (rather than the acoustically transparent fabric).

5. @BatMeckley can confirm hard front wall was farrrr superior for me. I had a soft one (felt) against Ruairi advice since I preferred the aesthetic lol, but room was too dead. Uncomfortable. When I switched I could hear much more depth and energy but everything still as crisp and clear. Highly recommend! 

Hope this helps some people on here. FYI we started my room from concrete block, bare bones so could frame things to hold treatment needed.

Will circle back with some better pics when I’m home. This community has helped me greatly.

Cheers friends!

author: Rollmottle
content:
Here are my impressions:

- Definitely well within the same ballpark. The room plays a big part in how these speakers sound.

- Cian’s monitors are closer together than mine and he sits closer than I do. Where I think I get a wider view of music in my room, in his room it feels more tightly focused. If we put it in terms of a frame on a wall, my frame feels like 5’ x 7’ and his feels like it’s 3’ x 5.’ Which makes sense given what we respectively do.

- There was a noticeable difference in presentation of the midrange, His room seems like it is helping focus the midrange in a different way than mine does. I feel like my room is less opinionated, with maybe a bit of bias to the low end, his feels a biased toward the midrange without the same bias toward the low end. Which again, makes a lot of sense given what we respectively do.

- The low end in his room is definitely tighter where mine is a bit less controlled. Both are totally viable and satisfying in different ways and either presentation wouldn’t get in your way.

- Vibe check is high. I covet his ceilings.

author: Rollmottle
content: Nice vibey spot! If you want to go down the rabbit hole all the way, the speakers should be all the way up against the back wall. Remove the treatment from the center there and put them right up against the wall. Where they are now, they look really wide and you'll still be feeling the effects of the gap between their position and back wall. You might be getting even more boundary effect from them being so close to the side walls as well. It might be counterintuitive to remove the treatment from the middle, but it really will probably help more than not. Yes, then you will have to deal with the big screen right in the sweet spot, but one step at a time lol.

author: austenballard
content:
Idk exactly how this applies to monitoring specifically, but if it helps to do a bunch of thinking up front so you do less thinking later when the clock is ticking and things that matter are on the line, I'm all for that, I think we all should be. I've been led to doing so by my own pathological tendencies but I don't think that approach is without legitimate merit.

In my view it connects to the theme that's come up a few times, most recently re: @cian riordan's monitoring situation vis-a-vis spending 10k to *remove doubt*. If something is going to take a psychological toll on you and prevent you from doing good work, or *nag at your soul*, then I sincerely believe you should go down the rabbit hole and understand what you're working with.

It's the same reason I value doing testing. Why I put in the time to confirm @BatMeckley's observations about Melodyne and write it up. Why I dug into the tech specs for Ableton Warp with @ALXCPH. Why many others in here have done deep dives on various things, like @Slow Hand did also with Ableton Warp. 

Does it sometimes stray into sweating minutiae that don't really matter? Absolutely. But - and here's the part that I think is critical - **we are making things**, and hopefully trying to make the best things we can. You're gonna have a hard time working out what's important and what is not important if you don't go deep once in a while, but you'll have an even harder time if you don't then come up for air and see if the minutiae are relevant to your *work* or not. (This is the trap I see audiophiles fall into, being as, you know, they're not making work like we are.)

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
@Zack Hames I remember shopping for an engagement ring. I was ready to spend $12k on the right ring, and feeling real grown up about it. But the first thing Michelle did was go to a local showroom and figure out exactly what she wanted, not thinking about budget. Just size, shape, color, & setting. 

I waited till the spring sale and went down to have a look and see what was what. It was $27k before tax. 

I can’t stress enough that Michelle is not bougie; she didn’t pick the fanciest or biggest or “most expensive” rock; she just found what she liked. 

I legit guffawed. And told the salesperson thank and was ready to leave. She looked at me and said “well what’s your budget?” I said $12.5. And tbh I was really fucking proud of that number walking in to the store, but when the saleswoman heard it she wasn’t just crestfallen, she was annoyed. Like I was wasting her time. To say it took the wind outta my sails was an understatement. 

A few months later I told the story to the right friend, who new the right guy. Long story short I got almost the exact same ring for $4k. (The Diamond business is a fucking war zone, literally.) 

Anyway, point is, don’t let these bougie Motherfuckers make you feel bad about being able to spend $20k building out your dream studio. That’s a big number in almost every world. 

You might not be able to do it the way you imagined, but you’re gonna get there. 100% you’ll end up with a great sounding room with a killer vibe, cause you know what you want and you’ll keep working till it’s right.

author: LAPhill
content:
@Zack Hames there are tiers to this. It'll be harder to suss out the quality of designers and contractors where you are, but get into studios there that are well-built and find out who did them. Decide what's most important to you (isolation? room response? vibe?) and allocate your resources from there. Do you really need that hardwood flooring, or would a laminate suffice? I cut corners on a few aspects of my studio, most of which turned out to be fine, but I'm now paying the price for something that likely could've been avoided had I spent more up front. 

I have colleagues that went with fancy architects/big name studio designers and spent twice as much as I did and had worse results. So price does not always equate to the final product.

author: LAPhill
content:
With windows, the one creature comfort I gave myself in my build was automatic blinds (black-out shades, in my case). They're expensive, but depending on which direction you're facing and how the sun hits you, it's nice to tweak at the push of a button instead of having to get up and ruin the flow. I have a skylight though, which it doesn't look like you have any windows up high - that was part of what sealed the deal for me.

author: Rollmottle

i will always recommend going into joists for any overhead installations, especially one of considerable weight. heavy duty drywall anchors could definitely work to spread and share the load between 4 single joist-installed anchors, but that assumes there's viable modern drywall up there to begin with. what appears to be drywall in my room for example, is old 1/8" fiber board, which does not hold anything. 

that may be fine for Itay's use case if there's drywall behind those wood planks, but best practice and peace of mind would be spanning the key anchor points across 2 joists and using longer chain or wire to make the connection.

author: Maxim
content:
So I'm currently doing all of this (removed screen as well). I'm not sold just yet. 

Few issues: the listening position is still best in my old spot (about 34% into the room). So I have to pump more sound than before to get the same "feeling". Phantom center is also not as clear.

Also, the idea of getting a triangle gets thrown out the window. I'm further away than they are apart. Bass of course is bigger (even with a -6db roll-off) but I'm not sure if it's actually useful. And it seems like the walls are now vibrating more (already had a neighbor asking what I'm up to).

And for some reason records that sounded great to me before now sound unlistenable and harsh in the upper mids. Not sure if this is true just yet though (see Walking on a Dream by Empire of the Sun). If this is what other people are also hearing maybe it's the detail I've been missing in the mids. Some songs are really painful.

On the plus side, the room is a bit "deader" and even now because I moved the treatment to the back (where previously there wasn't much). Also, reverb tails are very clear now. Before I couldn't really hear FX until I overdid them and dialed back. I'll try doing a mix like this and see if I intuitively make better decisions.

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: fwiw I've had good luck with a Samsung miniLED TV as a monitor

author: Bryan DiMaio
content:
so OLED is where every pixel is its own backlight, microLED is that but without burn-in (but also like $100k for one), and miniLED is an in between. Essentially it's a QLED (lots of colors and bright af) with a ton of backlight zones/full array local dimming. Essentially it has great color depth and brightness without OLED problems, though it doesn't quite match the pixel response (but is still quite fast) and it's not quite as many backlight zones (since not every single pixel is its own backlight like on OLED and microLED). Hopefully that's not too much word vomit lol

At the end of the day, I have an OLED in the living room and a miniLED as a computer monitor and for everyday use as a monitor this is great. The advantages you'd gain of going with an actual monitor that has DisplayPort are good if your computer doesn't have HDMI 2.1 since you'd then be able to hit 120Hz at 4k and it would feel quite buttery smooth

author: Tim O’Sullivan
content:
What Cian said. Old school cctv is the reliable, simple to troubleshoot and cheap. Especially if you only  have a couple cameras. Good enough vid quality, best latency. 

That said the modern ptz stuff is great and I’ve installed a few at different studios with no complaints. SDI is going to have better latency than hdmi, more reliable at longer distances and it’s a locking connector. Networking stuff really only useful when you have a bunch or rooms and cameras. If you’re cool with a fixed camera position then just get a fixed SDI cam and save some cash over the PTZ.

author: Shadowherb
content: from the research I've done, the whole "acoustic fabric" thing is snakeoil, all that matters is that the weave is loose enough that air passes through the membrane so it can interact with the absorption material behind it. when I built 12+ panels for my home studio I just went to the Walmart fabric section and did a "breath test", putting my hand behind the fabric and seeing if I could feel my breath through it. I think my panels work great and I payed $3-5/yd as opposed to some of the insane prices you find for fabric specifically designed for acoustic panels. aesthetics are obviously a factor, but those are my 2 cents!

author: Maxim
content:
I’d wholeheartedly recommend the Focal Clear MG. Out of the box they were my favorite in the 1-1.5k price range. I tested the HEDDs, Airpod Max, Audeze LCD-X and own the M50s and HD650s. 

I was looking for the headphone that gave me the best assortment of detail, fun, space, and „translation“ to speakers out of the box (without extra eq or another amp to power it outside of my UAD interface). 

For my taste the Focals fit that perfectly. Even hooked up to my laptop directly the sound was extremely fun, detailed and useful in making decisions. 

Also the look, comfort, travel case and extra pads are a nice touch. Only negative for me was the cable being a bit too short in a recording/moving around in a studio setting. But I wouldn’t use them for that anyways. 

AirPod Max (with noise canceling) would probably be second. They just lack the finer details and deep bass for me. 

Then the LCD-x (they are technically better than the Airpods but I wouldn’t prefer the LCDs in a real world setting. Only in the studio with some eq added).

HEDDs I so heavily disliked it wasn’t even funny. The UAD Interface can’t power them properly and they just sounded like a crappy and weird set of nearfield speakers playing from either side of your ear. Can’t even explain it.

author: peterlabberton
content:
This is the kind of nerdy tweaky shit I think this discord will appreciate: got my lil S1 control surface a few days ago, and used setting it up as an excuse to also play around with the arrangement of my tiny desk, and add some EQ to my monitors.

Tried the S1 behind my keyboard (too deep and potential for more reflections), and off to my left (weird neck craning all day), and landed here for now. Then busted out a mirror and angled my desk to avoid any reflections from the monitors at the listening position. Shot the room again and popped this EQ on the output in UAD Console (it’s finally good for something!!), and am very pleased with the new arrangement. 🎉

Ruairi might have a fit with this EQ curve, but I’m ABing it in and out and it’s definitely helpful, until I get my act together and build some membranes!

author: cian riordan
content:
So here’s the roundup on my dumb drum thing. This is a scrappy little experiment on my part to see if I can get a convincing drum sound in my little drum room. Before starting this, I had the idea in my mind that if a room is good for mixing, it must be good for recording! *Insert Game Show Buzzer* I ran into many of the things I didn’t like about the Barefoot Studio B Live room — and those things were exaggerated by a factor of 10. First of all, my room is very dead by design. It treats me great in mixing, but made for a real challenge when trying to get *some* sort of drum personality. I was also working with a pretty shitty old premier kit that hadn’t seen the light of day in half a decade. Shitty cymbals, very quickly tuned heads — I wasn’t setting myself up for success… but whatever.

The setup was a little ridiculous (minus a few utilitarian pieces):
Kick: Beta 52 -> Scully 280
Snare: SM57 -> Scully 280
OH Mono: Coles 4038 -> Ampex 351 -> 1176 (not compressing, just to trim gain before ‘tools)
OH L/R: U67s -> UTA pre (thanks Matt!)
Kick Room: U47 -> UTA Pre (again…)

This is where I ended up, without mixing, and with some quick playing and utility EQ/balancing. No compression except a limiter to bring up the level. While the actual drums themselves don’t sound amazing, I really struggled with getting any sort of energy out of the drums… it all just got sucked out. 

Here are the results if you care (don’t judge my shitty playing)

I think if it do this again I would:
1) Have a better sounding kit. Turns out, shit in.. shit out. I knew this. We all know this. But here I am.
2) Maybe put some sheets of plywood around to create some surface in the room. Just give it some life.
3) Not use the Scully. It’s so hard to get them to not sound distorty… I just don’t have enough pres on hand to have clean path for everything. Mix studio living.

So it goes…

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I have a Hilo goes AES to speakers and as my send/capture for the Massive Passive...you can't see it here but there is a rack under the screen where it sits. I have a side car off the side (the walls look pretty tight but they are actually the unf*ck mass loaded vinyl L things, so the room opens up more behind them). The sidecar is back from those...its got a apogee symphony taking the ins for my synths (also not really pictured -- just hangarounds from my production days for the fun of it sometimes), Hazelrigg VLC in there too.

There is sorta a whole room behind the listening position...its 30 feet long with a floating wall for absorption about 15 feet in so the studio is like 13x15 but acoustically its larger if that makes sense.

I do use streamdeck...but mainly to switch quickly between the hot ref in Wavelab and my master. I've gotten deep into Applescript which essentially handles all of the other Wavelab processes...it's almost finished but my streamdeck will essentially just launch those applications to do what I need. So I'd say it's very useful, but the coding I've been able to do will render it sorta meaningless for me (though convienent, I use it for other things like navigating websites when doing client outreach, etc which is very handy and makes my workflow like an order of magnitude quicker).

Chair is hag capisco. I love it. Had a serious back injury when I was younger so I'm pretty dialed into having things be ergonomic and I find it's great. Actually kinda rather uncomfortable...in a good way. You can't really slouch. Took some getting used to but it's interesting

author: Will Melones
content:
It took me waaaay too long to figure out the angles when I decided to get OCD about this for the first time ever this year. I ended up folding a little triangular piece of paper to use as a template against the wall.

I also took some long twine, taped it to the back of the base of each stand, and stretched it out to a location just behind the sweet spot. Figured if the twine landed at the center of the front of the stand, they were angled symmetrically at that spot. But then I didn’t have a protractor or a laser handy.

author: ALXCPH
content: Ofc. I have countless times been in sessions, where I’ve had to record something with a different producer, and I’ll want to do another take that’s just a little bit cleaner or better, and everyone else will be like “it’s fine, it’s great” but my ear still thinks it can be better. And I’ll get teased with being a perfectionist. But then when I do just listen and let it go, I’ll listen back a couple days later and realise, it was perfect for what it was, and the details I would hyper focus on, just gave the performance character or vibe and actually sound better than if I played it like a robot.

author: David Fuller
content: @chrissorem @BatMeckley fwiw I noticed the same thing about the 420s, they *definitely* are midfields - they need ~5 feet to integrate right.  And yeah, ||low end is *stupid* detailed a lot like the 6-2; that might be because they both have a very low box tuning. IIRC the 420 is around 30hz, the 6-2 is around 35hz||. I hear what you mean with the ||lean in the low mids|| thing but I think that might be an illusion because there's ||basically no harmonic or intermodulation distortion of note in the low end so they don't have a bunch of extra info the next octave and a half up||.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Has anyone gone down the rabbit hole of ways to manipulate your space to be more productive/focused? Things like lighting, wall colors, types of furniture or layout, temperature, acoustics based things, computer screen brightness, etc etc. 

Things that promote focus, creativity, allows for less stress/better focus. Could be literally anything

author: montrose recording
content: i second the hue system.  being able to save scenes for my early vs mid and late parts of the day keep me feeling like its a nice space to be in and inspired to be in the room

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Lots of great ideas here! I'm personally on the @Rollmottle train (also @cian riordan aesthetic is similarish)...I just agree aesthetically that I like the brighter/cleaner/warmer vibe. Of course your tastes may differ, but my lights dim like @montrose recording  said...it's really nice when it's getting later in the day to have some more dim lighting to match the outside a bit. 

Also really love to keep things ultra simple visually...the least amout of things around (even cords, etc) but again that's just me. Different things inspire us all.

Also big fan of keeping the digital environment very organized, as few things open as I need. I still certainly can get distracted like the rest of us. One thing I underestimated about running a full time mastering shop is just the number of interactions per day that are needed...and that can definitely take you out of the flow so I tend to keep it very contained...say only respond at certain points of the day and generally I deliver all my files at the end of the day in one batch. I'm sure some similar type of thing can be achieved for us all no matter the process. Still a work in progress over here of course!

My final thought is that the best focus enabler I've found is just good old fashioned hard-nosed exercise. Getting up early, squatting heavy, hard sprints...taking things to the limit (safely) really allow me personally to retain a very real sense of resilience and focus. And increase and double-down on discipline -- which in turn increases motivation often for me!

Best of luck! As far as I can tell, retaining focus in our current age is an eternally ongoing (and extremely valuable) skill to work on

author: Zach Hughes
content: I've been going down this rabbit hole recently. I purchased and have started using a phone lock box. Kinda hardcore. Not gonna be necessary for everyone. There's also a program called freedom (probably similar to focus app mentioned) I just got and will be experimenting with. Have a program called flux that changes the color hue of my screen as the day progresses to make it easier on the eyes. I think blue light earlier in the day and yellow ish light later in the day? Some science I don't really understand behind that. There's a huberman lab out there somewhere about it. I backlit my screen display with blue leds as well. Honestly one of the best things when I actually stick to it is trying to never sit for longer than an hour. Even just a 5 minute stand up walk around helps me immensely. Related I drink a ton of water and forces me to get up to go to the bathroom more often.

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: In the event of a single drive failure, is the replacement process pretty simple? Do I need to have the failed or failing drive still plugged in or would I just boot without it connected and a new one in its place and tell TrueNAS to replace it?

author: popthetrunk
content:
It’s super easy, If the failed drive is still useful in anyway to zfs(these blocks are good, but these are bad) it is useful to have it plugged in during a resilver. 

You don’t have to power down to replace a disk you just attach the power and data cables, remove the faulted disk in the gui(it will be yelling at you) and then you select replace with the new disk as soon as it spins up
